importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The incident occurred on October 19, 2025, during the Hispanic Heritage Night event, marking the date when the offensive message was displayed and the backlash began.

keyTakeAways: The San Jose Sharks displayed an offensive message on their scoreboard during Hispanic Heritage Night that appeared to praise Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), prompting public backlash.
The message, 'SJ SHARKS FANS LOVE ICE !! GET ‘EM BOYZ !', was deemed inappropriate and contrary to the values of the team and the community it serves.
The Sharks apologized, stating that the message was externally submitted and inadvertently displayed, and that it did not reflect the organization’s values.
The incident occurred during a celebratory event honoring the Bay Area’s vibrant Hispanic community, undermining the intended cultural and inclusive message of the event.
Fans expressed outrage, with one fan, Jessica Clark, stating she was 'appalled' and believed the message should have been caught during review processes.
The Sharks have launched an investigation into the origin of the message, acknowledging it as a serious error and a breach of community trust.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The San Jose Sharks apologized for displaying an offensive message on their scoreboard during their Hispanic Heritage Night celebration, which appeared to praise Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). The message, 'SJ SHARKS FANS LOVE ICE !! GET ‘EM BOYZ !', was criticized by fans as inappropriate and harmful, especially given the cultural significance of the event. The team acknowledged the message was externally submitted and inadvertently displayed, stating it did not reflect their values, and launched an investigation into its origin. The incident, occurring at the SAP Center during a game against the Pittsburgh Penguins, undermined the inclusive spirit of the event and sparked public backlash, with fans like Jessica Clark expressing shock and dismay.
title: San Jose Sharks Apologize for ‘Offensively Wordered Message’ Displayed During Hispanic Heritage Night
